articles.headline: Wisconsin Reels After Police Shooting and Second Night of Protests
articles.snippet: Jacob Blake, a Black resident of Kenosha, was shot in the back, setting off condemnations from Wisconsin’s governor and Joe Biden, the Democrats’ presidential nominee.
articles.abstract: Jacob Blake, a Black resident of Kenosha, was shot in the back, setting off condemnations from Wisconsin’s governor and Joe Biden, the Democrats’ presidential nominee.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Here’s what we know about the Jacob Blake shooting in Kenosha, Wisconsin.]
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman and Sarah Mervosh

articles.headline: Jerry Falwell Jr.’s Leadership at Liberty Appears Near End
articles.snippet: One of President Trump’s most prominent evangelical supporters, Mr. Falwell denied reports he had resigned from the university.
articles.abstract: One of President Trump’s most prominent evangelical supporters, Mr. Falwell denied reports he had resigned from the university.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Update: Jerry Falwell Jr. is officially out at Liberty University.]
articles.byline: By Ruth Graham, Elizabeth Dias and Frances Robles

articles.headline: Nominating Trump, Republicans Rewrite His Record
articles.snippet: President Trump and his party engaged in sweeping revisionism about his management of the coronavirus, his record on race relations and much else. And they painted a dystopian picture of what the nation would look like if Joseph R. Biden Jr. were ...
articles.abstract: President Trump and his party engaged in sweeping revisionism about his management of the coronavirus, his record on race relations and much else. And they painted a dystopian picture of what the nation would look like if Joseph R. Biden Jr. were president.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump and his political allies mounted a fierce and misleading defense of his political record on the first night of the Republican convention on Monday, while unleashing a barrage of attacks on Joseph R. Biden Jr. and the Democratic Party that were unrelenting in their bleakness.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin, Alexander Burns and Annie Karni

articles.headline: The Republicans Promised Uplift and Then Tried to Rewrite History
articles.snippet: On the first night of the party’s convention, President Trump painted a rosy portrait of his handling of the virus, and speakers warned of what they believe a Biden administration could bring.
articles.abstract: On the first night of the party’s convention, President Trump painted a rosy portrait of his handling of the virus, and speakers warned of what they believe a Biden administration could bring.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump was trying to rewrite history and enlist frontline Covid workers to the cause. The strain showed.

articles.headline: To Fight Apple and Google’s Grip, Fortnite Creator Mounts a Crusade
articles.snippet: Tim Sweeney, chief executive of Epic Games, the maker of Fortnite, has railed against tech power. “The market is out of control,” he said.
articles.abstract: Tim Sweeney, chief executive of Epic Games, the maker of Fortnite, has railed against tech power. “The market is out of control,” he said.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Tim Sweeney, chief executive and founder of the video game maker Epic Games, has antagonized the world’s most powerful technology giants since at least 2016.

articles.headline: Black Homeowners Face Discrimination in Appraisals
articles.snippet: Companies that value homes for sale or refinancing are bound by law not to discriminate. Black homeowners say it happens anyway.
articles.abstract: Companies that value homes for sale or refinancing are bound by law not to discriminate. Black homeowners say it happens anyway.
articles.lead_paragraph: Abena and Alex Horton wanted to take advantage of low home-refinance rates brought on by the coronavirus crisis. So in June, they took the first step in that process, welcoming a home appraiser into their four-bedroom, four-bath ranch-style house in Jacksonville, Fla.

articles.headline: With Hacks and Cameras, Beijing’s Electronic Dragnet Closes on Hong Kong
articles.snippet: Under a new national security law, the police are targeting the social media accounts of executives, politicians and activists. American internet giants are struggling to respond.
articles.abstract: Under a new national security law, the police are targeting the social media accounts of executives, politicians and activists. American internet giants are struggling to respond.
articles.lead_paragraph: To get onto his Facebook account, the police used Tony Chung’s body.

articles.headline: Trump’s Fights Are Their Fights. They Have His Back Unapologetically.
articles.snippet: Many supporters of President Trump said in interviews that he had succeeded on issues that matter to them. And they dismissed as unimportant the behavior that critics say makes him unfit for office.
articles.abstract: Many supporters of President Trump said in interviews that he had succeeded on issues that matter to them. And they dismissed as unimportant the behavior that critics say makes him unfit for office.
articles.lead_paragraph: DiAnna Schenkel is a law school graduate who once ran on the Democratic ticket for her city council. She voted twice for Barack Obama. A 59-year-old suburbanite in North Carolina, she worries about her Black son-in-law being racially profiled by the police, pulled over and beaten or worse.

articles.headline: How the U.K. Restarted Its Restaurant Industry: Paying Half the Bill
articles.snippet: Britons eager for a bargain have taken up the government’s “eat out to help out” offer. But how long will the resurgence last?
articles.abstract: Britons eager for a bargain have taken up the government’s “eat out to help out” offer. But how long will the resurgence last?
articles.lead_paragraph: When the British government told people they no longer had to stay home, it needed a convincing pitch to get everyone back outside and, crucially, spending money.
